Now twilight draws her dark'ning veil,</br>The owls their dwellings quit;</br>The pleasing, pensive hour, I hail,</br>For contemplation fit.
Forth from my humble cot I stray,</br>For well I love the time,</br>Or through the vale to take my way,</br>Or up the hill to climb.
Through trackless plains my steps to urge,</br>To penetrate the grove,</br>Or by the riv'let's rushy verge,</br>In thoughtful mood to rove.
Oft it's slow-winding course I trace,</br>Which leads where all must go,</br>To the still church-yard, that sad place,</br>Where many a friend lies low.
There, where it laves the sacred sod</br>With gently murmuring noise,</br>Full oft the "margent green" I've trod,</br>And tasted tranquil joys.
Beheld the Moon on silver car</br>Slow riding thro' the night;</br>Have seen, with thought sublime, each star</br>That lent its twinkling sight.
Or with some much-lov'd friend convers'd,</br>While swift the hours have fled,</br>Some friend who now is turn'd to dust,</br>And on whose grave I tread.
But ah!  by pale Diana's light,</br>Which now begins to beam;</br>His heart was kind and warm;</br>Whom I did most esteem.
Bright Virtue reign'd within his breast,</br>His heart was kind and warm;</br>And Nature too had done her best,</br>In fashioning his arm.
Full oft in rural solitude,</br>We've studied Wisdom's ways;</br>Full oft the Muse together woo'd,</br>In simple artless lays.
But now those happy hours are past,</br>No more to be enjoy'd;</br>The bud of genius, Death's rough blast</br>Has wither'd and destroy'd.
Close at yon solemn yew-tree's root,</br>In peace the poet sleeps;</br>Around his grave wild roses shoot,</br>And near, the willow weeps.
No sumptuous marble decks the green,</br>His praises to rehearse;</br>But on a rude carv'd stone is seen,</br>This tributary verse:
THE EPITAPH.</br>Here, in the silence of the tomb,</br>A humble bard lies low,</br>His faults, his virtues, and his doom,</br>The last great day will show.
Reader, if Nature to thy breast,</br>A feeling heart ne'er gave,</br>Pass on; but if with genius blest</br>Weep o'er "the poet's grave."</br>
